name: Michael Johnson
content:
This is a completely new direction. Whilst rooted in the ethos of the ‚ÄòPioneer‚Äô thinking it also crosses over into the ‚ÄòTaking a stand‚Äô narratives. We started to think that a flame could be a powerful symbol of Mozilla‚Äôs determination to remain the beacon for an open, accessible and equal internet for all, and something that a community gathers around for warmth.

As we started to experiment with flame symbolism, one simple design won through which simply merges an ‚ÄòM‚Äô and a flame. After some experimentation, we think a dot/pixellated form for this idea work nicely. It animates nicely, and might even be dynamically generated with lightweight code.

The logo is very nice to look at, and stands out. I like that there‚Äôs still some of the red in it, though it‚Äôs not afraid to expand it‚Äôs pallate. The circular pixels give a modern touch without coming off as too geeky or too cold. The logo is warm and inviting, while hinting at power. It‚Äôs flexible, able to take on any color while still keeping it‚Äôs form and distinctiveness.

I saw a few people say they didn‚Äôt see the M in the logo, but I liked it before I noticed anyway.

I like this design. The warmth, the flexibility, the uniqueness, and it just looks good. I would also definitely wear it.

Also one more thing:
Why not keep the current typeface for the wordmark? I can‚Äôt see a reason not to. It‚Äôs a very readable font and it‚Äôs been part of the wordmark for a while. Personally I think you should keep the typeface, but either way this design route is fantastic.

2. I see Mozilla as a fire, I definitely agree with the notion of it being a ‚Äúbeacon‚Äù and a ‚Äúwarm place to gather around‚Äù. In my mind it plays well with our notion of community.

3. Mozilla is also fighting, for the Open Web, for freedom on the Internet, for net neutrality, etc. The flame is a good symbol of such things.

Also, I really like the sub-brands you are showing here. They look far better than all the others I have seen so far.
